Course Description: Traditional economic analysis takes the rational individual as its starting point. Economic Sociology on the other hand encourages students to see rational self-interest and action as embedded in society, influenced by group dynamics, legal institutions, power, organizations and even culture.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to read and comprehend and present on Key Concepts in social science material.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to make cross-disciplinary connections between the sphere of 'economics' and social facts and to conceptualise the links between the Economy and society.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to understand and explain different methodological approaches of mainstream economics and sociology to develop a comparative understanding on contemporary issues.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to apply their knowledge of economic sociology to real-world scenarios.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Brief histories of Economics and Sociology
Formalism and Substanvism in Economic Sociology- Karl Polanyi
New Traditions of Economic Sociology- Swedberg

Reference Book: Durkheim, E. Division of Labour in Society (relevant chapters)
Granovetter, M. “Economic action and social structure: the problem of embeddedness”, AJS, Vol 91, Issue 3 November 1985
Granovetter, M. and R. Swedberg (eds) 2011. The sociology of Economic life.Westview: Colorado
